BE11:29am

Adjusted Pre Tax Profits for FY 2018/19 (£298m) have come in broadly in line with both consensus expectations (£299m) and with company guidance ("around £300m"). This guidance had been in place, unchanged, since May 2018 and we suspect that there are not many retailers in the UK delivering the kind of results they would have predicted a year ago (though, yet again, Dixons Carphone's Statutory Profits are much lower than its adjusted profits). Net debt of £265m (vs £249m a year previously) is also broadly in line with previous company guidance.

MOS Not sure BCA shareholders get the 6.65p divi - statement quite unclear to me
BE11:29am

The results for FY 2018/19, however, are likely to be overshadowed today by the guidance for FY 2019/20. The company is guiding for adjusted Pre Tax Profits this year to be around £210m. This is around 30% below current market expectations (according to Bloomberg consensus is currently forecasting £297m). The downgrade relates entirely to the group's UK mobile business, which is now expected to post losses of around £90m in FY 2019/20. - Whilst the market was already well aware that the UK Mobile was struggling, the scale of these downgrades will come as a disappointment to investors today and will inevitably lead to concerns as to how much worse things could get. Management, however, has stated that it is confident that FY 2019/20 will mark the trough for the UK Mobile business and that the division will break even again by FY 2021/22. Whilst this might seem optimistic, we think it important to bear in mind that the principal reason that UK Mobile is struggling is that the group is locked into punitive contracts with the UK network operators which require it to meet certain volume commitments, irrespective of market conditions, and that these contracts run out during FY 2020/21.-

11:29 am
BE11:29am

Although today will be dominated by the newsflow on Mobile, we think it worth highlighting that it accounts for only around 20% of group sales and less than 10% of group selling space. The rest of the group continues to trade well, is gaining market share and is expecting to grow profits in the year ahead.- Based on existing consensus forecasts and last night's closing price, Dixons Carphone is trading on 6.1x Cal 2019 earnings, 3.8x EBITDA with a 5.5% Dividend Yield. This compares with at UK General Retail sector trading on 13.1x, 8.2x and 3.4% respectively

BE11:30am

News: Dixons Carphone (DC) reported FY19 results with PBT of c.£298m (-22% yoy, vs company compiled consensus of £299m, Gse £291m). Revenues came in at £10.4bn, split UK £6.47 bn, Nordics £3.5 bn and Greece at £459 mn. Group LFL sales grew by +1% in FY19 split UK electricals +1%, UK mobile -4%, Nordics +3% and Greece +13%. Dixons Carphone has also announced a final dividend of 4.5p (full year 6.75p) and has a net debt position of £265 mn.
Guidance:
FY20E: DC expects headline PBT of c.£210m, Capex of £275m (inline with previous guidance) with net debt broadly flat year-on-year and plans to maintain full year dividend. UK mobile is expected to be significantly loss making in FY20E and will incur exceptional cash cost of c.£80m.
5 year transformation plan: DC expects EBIT margin improvement to at least 3.5% by FY23 (a year earlier than planned), gross savings of £200m (delivered two years earlier by FY22) and PBT of over £300m by F22E (GSe £288m).
What does it all mean? Other things equal, we expect Reuters PBT consensus for FY20E to decline by c.30% to £210m (-30% yoy) reflecting DC’s update guidance.
Valuation: Our 12-month price target of 148p is based on a DCF. We are Neutral rated.
Key risks: (-) Further slowdown in the UK demand environment is a key near/mid-term risk, (+) innovative product cycle. (-) Key structural risks: increased pure-play competition in electricals; relationships with MNOs and risk of disintermediation in UK mobile; higher penetration of SIM-only/SIM-free phones; changes in consumer preference.

The argument underpinning all this is that Rocket has E1.5bn or so of unlisted investments that are being valued at nothing or nearly nothing by the market.

BE11:41am

We see a strong rationale behind a potential buyback and taking the company private. Management has several times in the past highlighted its frustration with current share price levels and LPV valuations not replicated in Rocket’s share price – which looks unlikely to change short term. The company selling down its shareholdings in Delivery Hero, HelloFresh, Home24 and Westwing (followed by a successful IPO of Jumia) has also raised questions in regards to next steps in the company’s strategy.
 While a buyback would probably be a sensible move in terms of value generation, we question the funding potential. Rocket’s share price is down 30% since the company’s IPO and investors are, in our view, unlikely to accept a premium of less than 30%, leading to a potential market cap of greater than €5bn at acquisition. With CEO Oliver Samwer owning c44% (through Global Founders/other holdings), such a move would absorb almost all of Rocket’s current net cash balance (€3.1bn as of Q119) with limited firepower for additional acquisitions/new launches – we would be surprised at such a move.

11:45 am
BE11:46am

Last night, Delivery Hero announced that it was increasing its guidance for FY 2019 revenue by €200m from €1.1bn-1.2bn to €1.3bn-1.4bn. This 17-18% increase in expectations is a very substantial step-up and marks the latest in a series of upgrades that the company has issued since its IPO in 2017. This is the largest of those upgrades by some magnitude.
● While our revenue estimates of €1,167m was already above consensus of €1,130m, reflecting our view that the company will continue to see a stronger-than-expected return on the incremental investment that the group has been making, the scale of this latest increase is impressive. Management now expects to maintain revenue growth of 90-100% right through the year. This reflects both the underlying growth in the group’s key markets, which remain underpenetrated with regard to online food marketplace usage, as well as the return that Delivery Hero is seeing on its stepped up investment plan, which was put into place in H2 of 2018. It should be noted that only 10% of the €200m upgrade comes from incremental revenue generated on the new investments in 2019: the bulk of the return will come in 2020.
● Indeed the strong returns that the group is making on its investments (primarily marketing, at least since inception) has prompted management to announce that it will invest up to another €100m in H2 2019. That means an EBITDA downgrade, of course, but we believe that the market ought to respond positively to the move. As Uber has made very clear, both ride-hailing and food delivery are in landgrab phase, and the ultimate winner ought to be the one that has achieves market dominance. We see a difference in terms of ride-hailing and food delivery, though. Restaurants are less likely than drivers to switch between platforms, we think, given the tight integration that is being put in place with EPOS systems in the restaurants. We note also a generally low level of churn on food delivery platforms after the first few orders have been made.

BE11:46am

Management has noted that the EBITDA guidance for Middle East and Europe remains, even if group EBITDA will now be around €100m lower in 2019 than previously forecast. That suggests that the bulk of the outperformance is coming in Latin America and Asia. Management has also noted that the bulk of the incremental investment will go into those markets. With strong results coming from the South Korean business as at the last set of results (management noted that growth in this market was almost into triple digits), it seems likely that Delivery Hero is stepping up the pressure in this market, where we think there is huge potential for consolidation in the medium term. We note that the sale of the German operations to Takeaway, which was achieved at an industry-high revenue multiple (that continues to rise given the increase in the Takeaway share price which formed part of the consideration in the transaction) came on the back of an increased push by Delivery Hero in that market. If a tougher competitive approach by Delivery Hero in South Korea were also to prompt consolidation in that market, there could be huge upside (beyond that being created by building a larger business through greater investment).
● We continue to believe that Delivery Hero is substantially undervalued versus peers. As we have stated in the past, we think that the markets in which it operates are generally more attractive than those that the peers are in, with a much higher order frequency rate, driving higher revenue per customer. On the flip side, the emerging-market-nature of many of these markets mean that key costs (labour and marketing) should be lower. Ultimately that should drive higher margins and profit per customer, in our view.

TrustMyUnit Wayne: I promise that 5 stars in TrustPilot ratings is no problem if you're paying them every month!
BE11:47am

Barclays also buyers.

Bluesky21 Amazon now a major shareholder in Deliveroo
11:47 am
BE11:47am

One of the key questions on Delivery Hero in the last year has been: “is all the investment going in actually going to yield a positive return?”. We started to get some positive signals in the Q1 results, but last night’s trading statement gives us a much firmer idea – it appears the answer is very much yes. Raised guidance points to a c15% underlying revenue upgrade to 2020E based on trends they have seen in Q2 (and notably more to 2020E as cohorts contribute for a full year and scale). True the revenue uplift is somewhat inflated by the shift to own delivery, but clearly order momentum is good too (and coming in emerging markets where own delivery could work at scale). They have taken the opportunity to announce €100m more EBITDA investment in 2H vs current consensus models – but that is far more digestible by public markets given there is now very clear evidence of a return coming through (and they say customer acquisition costs are flat to down). Of course competition in their markets is still evolving rapidly and funding isn’t showing signs of drying up any time soon, but this statement definitely reassures value is being created.

We have been flagging the inconsistency in modelling when it comes to Delivery Hero’s prior guidance (it always made sense that cohorts acquired could scale through the year and drive outperformance), and flagging upgrades to orders in consensus as the catalyst for this stock to rerate. On 0.6x EV/GMV ex c€0.6bn of associate stakes (which themselves need to be marked up given momentum in Rappi and Glovo), this stock is standout cheap. There also remains the potential for M&A to be part of the story, with several markets that could still consolidate – from a management team that has been very good at M&A until this point. Reiterate firmly Overweight.
